column1: Santa Rosa (Spanish for '"Saint Rose"') is a city and the county seat of Sonoma County
column2: in the North Bay region of the Bay Area in California. Its estimated 2019 population was 176
column3: 753. Santa Rosa is the largest city in California's Wine Country and Redwood Coast
column4: as well as the fifth most populous city in the Bay Area after San Jose
column6: Oakland
column7: and Fremont; and the 27th most populous city in California.

column1: Santa Rosa was founded in 1833 and named after Saint Rose of Lima.  Before the arrival of Europeans
column2: the Santa Rosa Plain was home to a strong and populous tribe of Pomo natives known as the Bitakomtara. The Bitakomtara controlled the area closely
column3: barring passage to others until permission was arranged. Those who entered without permission were subject to harsh penalties. The tribe gathered at ceremonial times on Santa Rosa Creek near present-day Spring Lake Regional Park. Upon the arrival of Europeans
column4: the Pomos were decimated by smallpox brought from Europe. By 1900 the Pomo population had decreased by 95%.The first known permanent European settlement of Santa Rosa was the homestead of the Carrillo family
column6: who settled the Sonoma pueblo and Petaluma area. In the 1830s
column8: the family of María López de Carrillo built an adobe house on their Rancho Cabeza de Santa Rosa land grant
column9: just east of what later became downtown Santa Rosa. Allegedly
column12: before the Carrillos built their adobe in the 1830s
column13: Spanish and Mexican settlers from nearby Sonoma and other settlements to the south raised livestock in the area and slaughtered animals at the fork of the Santa Rosa Creek and Matanzas Creek
column14: near the intersection of modern-day Santa Rosa Avenue and Sonoma Avenue. This is supposedly the origin of the name of Matanzas Creek as
column15: because of its use as a slaughtering place
column16: the confluence came to be called La Matanza.

column8: but by 1900 it was being overtaken by many other newer population centers in the San Francisco Bay Area and Southern California. According to a 1905 article in the Press Democrat newspaper reporting on the "Battle of the Trains"

column1: Famed director Alfred Hitchcock filmed his thriller Shadow of a Doubt in Santa Rosa in 1943; the film gives glimpses of Santa Rosa in the 1940s. Many of the downtown buildings seen in the film no longer exist due to major reconstruction following the strong earthquakes in October 1969. However
column2: some
column3: like the rough-stone Northwestern Pacific Railroad depot and the prominent Empire Building (built in 1910 with a gold-topped clock tower)
column4: still survive.  A scene at the bank was filmed at the corner of Fourth Street and Mendocino Avenue (at present day Old Courthouse square); the Kress building on Fourth Street is also visible. However
column5: the courthouse and bank are now gone. The Coen brothers' 2001 film The Man Who Wasn't There is set in Santa Rosa c. 1949.

column1: Santa Rosa grew following World War II because it was the location for Naval Auxiliary Landing Field Santa Rosa
column2: the remnants of which are now located in southwest Santa Rosa. The city was a convenient location for San Francisco travelers bound for the Russian River.

column1: Santa Rosa annexed the community of Roseland in November 2017.
Beginning on the night of October 8
column3: five percent of the city's homes were destroyed in the Tubbs Fire
column5: 000-acre wildfire that claimed the lives of at least 19 people in Sonoma County. Named after its origin near Tubbs Lane and Highway 128 in adjacent Napa County
column6: the fire became a major section of the most destructive and third deadliest firestorm in California history. Most homes in the Coffey Park
column8: and Fountain Grove neighborhoods were destroyed.

column1: A notable exception to the destruction in the area was the protection of more than 1
column2: 000 animals at the renowned Safari West Wildlife Preserve northeast of Santa Rosa. All of the preserve's animals were saved by owner Peter Lang
column3: who
column4: at age 76
column5: single-handedly fought back the flames for more than 10 hours using garden hoses.The fire burned strongly for over seven days
column6: bringing the largest aerial attack in history to Sonoma County skies. Some of the airplanes include a massive Boeing 747 Supertanker
column11: and Boeing CH-47 Chinook helicopter. Every police agency in the San Francisco Bay Area was called in to help. Firefighting crews from across California and as far away as Australia came to aid in extinguishing the fire. The fires
column12: alongside the December 2017 Southern California wildfires
column13: comprised the most destructive year of California wildfires on record.

column1: Santa Rosa lies on the Santa Rosa Plain. The city's eastern extremities stretch into the Valley of the Moon
column2: and the Sonoma Creek watershed known as the Sonoma Valley. The city's western edge lies in the Laguna de Santa Rosa catchment basin.

column1: The city is in the watershed of Santa Rosa Creek
column2: which rises on Hood Mountain and discharges to the Laguna de Santa Rosa. Tributary basins to Santa Rosa Creek lying significantly in the city are Brush Creek
column3: Matanzas Creek
column4: and Piner Creek. Other water bodies within the city include Fountaingrove Lake
column6: and Santa Rosa Creek Reservoir.

column1: The prominent visual features east of the city include Bennett Peak
column2: Mount Hood
column3: and Sonoma and Taylor Mountains.

column1: Santa Rosa has a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csb) with cool
column2: wet winters and warm
column3: dry summers. In the summer
column4: fog and low overcast often move in from the Pacific Ocean during the evenings and mornings. They usually clear up to warm
column5: sunny weather by late morning or noon before returning in the later evening but will occasionally linger all day. Average annual rainfall is 32.20 inches (818 mm)
column6: falling on 74 days annually. The wettest year was 1983 with 63.07 inches (1
column7: 602 mm) and the driest year was 1976 with 11.38 inches (289 mm). The most rainfall in one month was 19.42 inches (493 mm) in February 1998 and the most rainfall in 24 hours was 5.23 inches (133 mm) on December 19
column8: 1981. Measurable snowfall is rare in the lowlands
column9: but light amounts sometimes fall in the nearby mountains.

column1: There are an average of 28.9 days with highs of 90 °F (32 °C) or more and an average of 30.2 days with lows reaching the freezing mark. The record high was 113 °F (45 °C) on July 11
column3: and the record low was 9 °F (−13 °C) on December 25

column1: Santa Rosa lies atop the Healdsburg-Rodgers Creek segment of the Hayward-Rodgers Creek Fault System. The Working Group on California Earthquake Probabilities estimated a minimum 27 percent chance of a magnitude 6.7 or greater earthquake on this segment by 2037.On November 21
column3: the United States Geological Survey released a map detailing the results of a new tool that measures ground shaking during an earthquake. The map determined that the 1906 San Francisco earthquake was most powerful in an area between Santa Rosa and what is now Sebastopol
column4: causing more damage in Santa Rosa (for its size) than any other city affected.On October 1
column6: two earthquakes of magnitudes 5.6 and 5.7 shook Santa Rosa
column7: damaging about 100 structures. They were the strongest quakes to affect the city since 1906. The epicenters were about two miles (3 km) north of Santa Rosa.

column2: much of Santa Rosa's remaining undisturbed area is on its urban fringe. However
column3: the principal wildlife corridors of Santa Rosa Creek and its tributaries flow right through the heart of the town. Great blue herons
column4: great egrets
column5: snowy egrets and black-crowned herons nest in the trees of the median strip on West Ninth Street as well as along Santa Rosa Creek and downtown. Deer often are spotted roaming the neighborhoods nearer the eastern hills
column6: as deep into town as Franklin Avenue and the McDonald area; rafters of wild turkeys are relatively common in some areas; and mountain lions are occasionally observed within city limits. Raccoons and opossums are a common sight throughout the city
column8: and rabbits may be regularly seen in the more rural areas. In addition
column9: the city borders and then wraps around the northern end of Trione Annadel State Park
column10: which itself extends into the Sonoma Mountains and Sonoma Valley. Trione-Annadel State Park also adjoins Spring Lake County Park and Howarth Park
column11: forming one contiguous park system that enables visitors to venture into wild native habitats.

column1: The Sonoma County Philharmonic performs at the Santa Rosa High School Performing Arts Auditorium. It is a 65-member all-volunteer orchestra that has presented hundreds of free and low-cost concerts throughout Sonoma County over the past 15 years. The orchestra is made up of professional-level local musicians who volunteer their time.

The Press Democrat is published in Santa Rosa and is the largest daily newspaper in the North Bay. It is descended from the Sonoma Democrat
column2: founded in 1857. Local business papers include the North Bay Business Journal and NorthBay biz. The North Bay Bohemian is a free weekly alternative. column1: The Santa Rosa Police Department currently has 259 employees
column2: of which 172 are sworn peace officers. Its budget is more than $40 million
column3: comprising more than one third of the city's General Fund budget. Police shootings in 2007 led to calls for an independent civilian police review board.

column1: The Santa Rosa Fire Department provides fire protection and emergency medical services.The Santa Rosa Fire Department
column2: like many departments across the United States
column3: made its start as a volunteer organization on February 12
column4: 1861. Decades later in 1894 the Department made its transition to a paid organization. In 1906 a massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake destroyed most of Santa Rosa. The department’s grew to 100 firefighters in 1983 with the addition of the city of Roseland to the SRFD responsibility area. Many members of the department serve as part of the California Task Force 4
column5: one of the eight FEMA Urban Search and Rescue Task Forces throughout the state. The team
column6: which is deployed as part of the nation's response to disasters both within and outside of the United States
column7: specializes in dealing with large-scale disasters.
